qas.question: Which motor areas of the brain control breathing and swallowing?
At the lowest level of the brain and spinal cord, are what areas?
The red nucleus controls what part(s) of the body?

answers.text: coordinating movements of the arms and legs

qas.question: A strip of tissue found at the edge of the frontal lobe is called what?
The primary motor cortex sends signals to the spinal cord through what?

context: The brain contains several motor areas that project directly to the spinal cord. At the lowest level are motor areas in <a0_0><a1_0>the medulla and pons<a1_0/>,<a0_0/> which control stereotyped movements such as walking, breathing, or swallowing. At a higher level are areas in the midbrain, such as the red nucleus, which is responsible for <a2_0>coordinating movements of the arms and legs<a2_0/>. At a higher level yet is the <a3_0>primary motor cortex<a3_0/>, a strip of tissue located at the posterior edge of the frontal lobe. The primary motor cortex sends projections to the subcortical motor areas, but also sends a massive projection directly to the spinal cord, through the <a4_0>pyramidal tract.<a4_0/> This direct corticospinal projection allows for precise voluntary control of the fine details of movements. Other motor-related brain areas exert secondary effects by projecting to the primary motor areas. Among the most important secondary areas are the premotor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
